pages.name: Select Interests

choices.value: platforms
choices.text: Modernizing platforms
choices.description: Ensure your organization is poised to provide the platform flexibility and scalability to manage demand.

choices.value: apps
choices.text: Modernizing applications
choices.description: Understand how you can modernize your development and address the best choices for future deployment.

choices.value: automation
choices.text: Automating IT

pages.title: Your Ready-to-Accelerate Assessment begins here
pages.description:
Select each area that applies to your business goals.
The estimated time to complete each section is 8-10 minutes.

elements.name: platforms_env_q1
elements.title: What is your department’s / organization’s main responsibility?

choices.value: Infrastructure delivery
choices.text: Infrastructure delivery

choices.value: Software Engineering
choices.text: Software Engineering

choices.value: Operations and software/infrastructure  support
choices.text: Operations and software/infrastructure  support

elements.name: platforms_env_q2
elements.title: What is the size of your department?

elements.name: platforms_env_q3
elements.title: Which of the following practices/methodologies are implemented in your organization?

choices.value: 0#Waterfall
choices.text: Waterfall

choices.value: 40#Agile
choices.text: Agile

choices.value: 60#DevOps
choices.text: DevOps

choices.value: 100#DevSecOps
choices.text: DevSecOps

elements.name: platforms_env_q4
elements.title: How is software and infrastructure deployed in your organization?

choices.value: 0#Manual
choices.text: Manually

choices.value: 10#We have some basic automation (e.g: scripts)
choices.text: With some basic automation (e.g., scripts)

choices.value: 40#Automation (e.g: Ansible, Terraform, Puppet, Chef, etc.)
choices.text: With automation (e.g., Ansible, Terraform, Puppet, Chef)

choices.value: 100#Advanced automation using IaC principles (e.g: Ansible + CI/CD)
choices.text: With advanced automation using infrastructure-as-code principles (e.g., Ansible + CI/CD)

elements.name: platforms_dev_q1
elements.title: On which of the following does your development process allow you to run workloads?

choices.value: 0#IaaS / VM only
choices.text: IaaS (Infrastructure-as-a-Service) / Virtual Machine (VM) only

choices.value: 40#PaaS / container platform
choices.text: PaaS (Platform-as-a-Service) / container platform

choices.value: 60#SaaS (Software-as-a-Service)
choices.text: SaaS (Software-as-a-Service)

choices.value: 60#FaaS (Function-as-a-Service)
choices.text: FaaS (Function-as-a-Service)

elements.name: platforms_dev_q2
elements.title: Which option best describes your current testing process?

choices.value: 0#Manual
choices.text: Manual

choices.value: 20#Automated builds / continuous integration
choices.text: Automated builds / continuous integration

choices.value: 40#Continuous deployment
choices.text: Continuous deployment

choices.value: 100#Test-driven development
choices.text: Test-driven development

elements.name: platforms_dev_q3
elements.title: Do you have influence on the development platforms your company purchases or uses?

choices.value: item1
choices.text: I have little to no influence.

choices.value: item2
choices.text: I have some influence.

choices.value: item3
choices.text: I am part of the decision making team.

elements.name: platforms_dev_q4
elements.title: How fast can you get code from development to production?

choices.value: 100#Minutes
choices.text: Minutes

choices.value: 60#Hours
choices.text: Hours

choices.value: 40#Days
choices.text: Days

choices.value: 0#A week or longer
choices.text: A week or longer

elements.name: platforms_dev_q5
elements.title: What is your typical application release cycle?

choices.value: 100#Daily
choices.text: Daily

choices.value: 60#Weekly
choices.text: Weekly

choices.value: 40#Monthly
choices.text: Monthly

choices.value: 10#Quarterly
choices.text: Quarterly

choices.value: 0#Longer cycles
choices.text: Longer cycles

elements.name: platforms_dev_q6
elements.title: Where is the development platform that you use most often for your company?

choices.value: 0#Laptop
choices.text: Laptop

choices.value: 10#VDI (virtual desktop infrastructure)
choices.text: VDI (virtual desktop infrastructure)

choices.value: 100#Cloud-based IDE
choices.text: Cloud-based integrated development environment (IDE)

elements.name: platforms_ops_q1
elements.title: How many clouds (private, public) does your organization currently use?

choices.value: 0#None
choices.text: None
1 to 2

choices.value: 60#3 or more
choices.text: 3 or more

elements.name: platforms_ops_q2
elements.title: How are you managing your cloud(s) resources?

choices.value: 0#Not applicable
choices.text: Not applicable

choices.value: 10#Using the cloud vendor's web UI
choices.text: Using the cloud vendor's web UI

choices.value: 20#Consuming the cloud vendor's API
choices.text: Consuming the cloud vendor's API

choices.value: 40#Using a centralized cloud management platform (CMP)
choices.text: Using a centralized cloud management platform (CMP)

choices.value: 100#Fully automated, so no user-to-cloud interaction needed
choices.text: Fully automated, so no user-to-cloud interaction needed

elements.name: platforms_ops_q3
elements.title: What is your lead time for change?
elements.description: (For example, how long does it take to add capacity?)

choices.value: 100#Hours
choices.text: Hours

choices.value: 40#Days
choices.text: Days

choices.value: 10#Weeks
choices.text: Weeks

choices.value: 0#Months
choices.text: Months

elements.name: platforms_ops_q4
elements.title: What is your strategy to migrate in-house workloads to the cloud?

choices.value: 0#We have no strategy.
choices.text: We have no strategy.

choices.value: 10#We’re re-platforming (moving pockets into the cloud—private or public cloud).
choices.text: We’re re-platforming (moving pockets into the cloud—private or public cloud).

choices.value: 20#Our primary strategy is to run a private cloud.
choices.text: Our primary strategy is to run a private cloud.

choices.value: 40#We intend to move as much as possible to the public cloud.
choices.text: We intend to move as much as possible to the public cloud.

choices.value: 60#We intend to operate in a hybrid cloud model.
choices.text: We intend to operate in a hybrid cloud model.

elements.name: appdev_env_1
elements.title: How are software projects organized and delivered?

choices.value: 0#Follow a sequential process of analysis, design, implementation, testing, and release
choices.text: Follow a sequential process of analysis, design, implementation, testing, and release

choices.value: 20#Some iterative practices within specific teams, supporting delivery of larger programs
choices.text: Some iterative practices within specific teams, supporting delivery of larger programs

choices.value: 40#An iterative delivery approach with a product backlog, definition of done, and retrospectives, with a hand-off to operations that is largely independent of software development
choices.text: An iterative delivery approach with a product backlog, definition of done, and retrospectives, with a hand-off to operations that is largely independent of software development

choices.value: 60#Business, application development, and delivery have aligned agile practices, ownership of production is within a cross-functional application team
choices.text: Business, application development, and delivery have aligned agile practices, ownership of production is within a cross-functional application team

choices.value: 100#Agile process with quantifiable metrics based on systems in production, fast feedback loops, designed to verify and quantify strategic goals and desired business outcomes
choices.text: Agile process with quantifiable metrics based on systems in production, fast feedback loops, designed to verify and quantify strategic goals and desired business outcomes

elements.name: appdev_env_2
elements.title: What best describes the level of governance and control within your organization?

choices.value: 0#No commonly implemented change policy, new changes can be introduced at any point through software delivery life cycle
choices.text: No commonly implemented change policy, new changes can be introduced at any point through software delivery life cycle

choices.value: 10#Change policy is sometimes bypassed for expediency, or change seen as critical to success
choices.text: Change policy is sometimes bypassed for expediency, or change seen as critical to success

choices.value: 20#Standard processes and architectures have developed over time, with addendums to support some new technologies and capabilities, but lack of ownership has led to complications and a low understanding of the rationale in some cases
choices.text: Standard processes and architectures have developed over time, with addendums to support some new technologies and capabilities, but lack of ownership has led to complications and a low understanding of the rationale in some cases

choices.value: 60#Common approaches support the delivery and architecture across the software delivery life cycle, incorporating good levels of transparency and adaptability
choices.text: Common approaches support the delivery and architecture across the software delivery life cycle, incorporating good levels of transparency and adaptability

choices.value: 100#Processes in place allow measurement of the business value of multiple software versions running simultaneously in production, coupled with team-level authority to make end-of-life decisions on specific versions
choices.text: Processes in place allow measurement of the business value of multiple software versions running simultaneously in production, coupled with team-level authority to make end-of-life decisions on specific versions

elements.name: appdev_env_3
elements.title: What best describes the process of determining and implementing change to software systems?

choices.value: 0#Future changes driven by immediate issues, faults and customer requirements with no consideration of the market
choices.text: Future changes driven by immediate issues, faults, and customer requirements with no consideration of the market

choices.value: 10#Changes aligned to a product roadmap driven by a common understanding of the potential market
choices.text: Changes aligned to a product roadmap driven by a common understanding of the potential market

choices.value: 20#Introduction of experimental changes designed to test market response
choices.text: Introduction of experimental changes designed to test market response

choices.value: 40#An evolutionary product roadmap defined around a researched view of market needs
choices.text: An evolutionary product roadmap defined around a researched view of market needs

choices.value: 100#Bold introductions of new features, tackling established use cases in innovative new ways
choices.text: Bold introductions of new features, tackling established use cases in innovative new ways

elements.name: appdev_env_4
elements.title: How do you manage work in progress?

choices.value: 0#New work items tackled somewhat reactively, with significant new work requiring project managers to negotiate and secure necessary resources and people
choices.text: New work items tackled somewhat reactively, with significant new work requiring project managers to negotiate and secure necessary resources and people

choices.value: 10#Individual teams operate their own prioritized product backlogs, task and issue tracking. Engineers are frequently assigned to production support issues. Multiple systems used to track software and production issues.
choices.text: Individual teams operate their own prioritized product backlogs, task and issue tracking. Engineers are frequently assigned to production support issues. Multiple systems used to track software and production issues.

choices.value: 20#Application support roles incorporated within development teams and working from a shared backlog and issue register. Planned development iterations frequently deliver fewer than expected changes, typically due to priority production issues taking focus.
choices.text: Application support roles incorporated within development teams and working from a shared backlog and issue register. Planned development iterations frequently deliver fewer than expected changes, typically due to priority production issues taking focus.

choices.value: 100#Product owners have tight control over backlogs and have an effective prioritization and estimation mechanism that directly aligns the business. All stakeholders accept that work in progress needs to be actively restricted to achieve quality. Features are now prioritized toward meeting strategic goals.
choices.text: Product owners have tight control over backlogs and have an effective prioritization and estimation mechanism that directly aligns the business. All stakeholders accept that work in progress needs to be actively restricted to achieve quality. Features are now prioritized toward meeting strategic goals.

elements.name: appdev_env_5
elements.title: What is your organization’s approach to technical debt ***(i.e., the implied cost of additional rework caused by choosing an easy, limited solution now instead of using a better approach that would take longer)***?

choices.value: 0#High technical debt, with lack of urgency or very little progress of reducing it
choices.text: High technical debt, with lack of urgency or very little progress of reducing it.

choices.value: 10#Technical debt recognized and is occasionally included with work plans
choices.text: Technical debt recognized and is occasionally included with work plans.

choices.value: 60#Technical debt being actively managed
choices.text: Technical debt being actively managed.

choices.value: 40#Low technical debt but does block fully automated continuous delivery
choices.text: Low technical debt but does block fully automated continuous delivery.

choices.value: 100#Anything that interferes with agility is regarded as technical debt and actively removed as a matter of priority.
choices.text: Anything that interferes with agility is regarded as technical debt and actively removed as a matter of priority.

elements.name: appdev_env_6
elements.title: Do you report any key performance indicators on software development and delivery?

choices.value: 0#Reports on software delivery performance are not habitually created, but instead generated through occasional auditing processes.
choices.text: Reports on software delivery performance are not habitually created, but instead generated through occasional auditing processes.

choices.value: 10#Some common metrics covering aspects of the software delivery process and runtime software behavior are generally reported within teams, but not necessarily reported across teams as a matter of course.
choices.text: Some common metrics covering aspects of the software delivery process and runtime software behavior are generally reported within teams, but not necessarily reported across teams as a matter of course.

choices.value: 40#Common metrics are aggregated and used to report specific performance of application life-cycle stages.
choices.text: Common metrics are aggregated and used to report specific performance of application life-cycle stages.

choices.value: 60#Software delivery performance is consistently, automatically measured across all applications teams, with full visibility to all stakeholders.
choices.text: Software delivery performance is consistently, automatically measured across all applications teams, with full visibility to all stakeholders.

choices.value: 100#There is continuous tracking of software delivery performance measures factored into future planning, supporting continuous improvement.
choices.text: There is continuous tracking of software delivery performance measures factored into future planning, supporting continuous improvement.

elements.name: appdev_dev_1
elements.title: Do multiple teams within your organization create and share development standards in a consistent, standardized manner?

choices.value: 0#It’s difficult to find information or necessary contacts within our organization.
choices.text: It’s difficult to find information or necessary contacts within our organization.

choices.value: 10#Knowledge sharing within teams is good, but there’s low visibility into other areas, with a tendency to reinvent solutions to common problems.
choices.text: Knowledge sharing within teams is good, but there’s low visibility into other areas, with a tendency to reinvent solutions to common problems.

choices.value: 20#Although limited, there’s a general willingness to cooperate across silos.
choices.text: Although limited, there’s a general willingness to cooperate across silos.

choices.value: 40#There is an emergence of collaboration, meritocracy, transparency, and open exchange of ideas.
choices.text: There is an emergence of collaboration, meritocracy, transparency, and open exchange of ideas.

choices.value: 100#Our organization actively cultivates and encourages open exchange with external parties.
choices.text: Our organization actively cultivates and encourages open exchange with external parties.

elements.name: appdev_dev_2
elements.title: Which best describes how your organization begins building new applications?

choices.value: 0#No common approach; we typically develop new approaches across teams, or for new apps, sometimes using existing work as a basis using a copy and paste method.There is a commonly shared understanding of software development stages, with some common components being reused to support specifics. Manual intervention is needed to promote build artifacts across life-cycle stages.
choices.text: No common approach; we typically develop new approaches across teams, or for new apps, sometimes use existing work as a basis using a copy and paste method. There is a commonly shared understanding of software development stages, with some common components being reused to support specifics. Manual intervention is needed to promote build artifacts across life-cycle stages.

choices.value: 10#There are examples of some application teams introducing significant amounts of automation within their build and delivery pipelines, but these examples are not widespread and have low adoption.
choices.text: There are examples of some application teams introducing significant amounts of automation within their build and delivery pipelines, but these examples are not widespread and have low adoption.

choices.value: 40#There is a centrally defined process with supporting services and tools supporting high levels of build and delivery automation across development, testing, and production that is commonly adopted and adhered to within the development community. There are few opportunities for teams to customize the process, or introduce different technologies (for example, different programming languages) without breaking away from the standard mechanisms.
choices.text: There is a centrally defined process with supporting services and tools supporting high levels of build and delivery automation across development, testing, and production that is commonly adopted and adhered to within the development community. There are few opportunities for teams to customize the process, or introduce different technologies (for example, different programming languages) without breaking away from the standard mechanisms.

choices.value: 100#There is a modular and extensible, reusable, and highly automated, standard approach for software builds and delivery that allows for specific application customization and targeted improvements.
choices.text: There is a modular and extensible, reusable, and highly automated, standard approach for software builds and delivery that allows for specific application customization and targeted improvements.

elements.name: appdev_dev_3
elements.title: Which best describes your application development architecture?

choices.value: 0#Ad hoc choice of application platforms and tooling, limited understanding of contemporary architectural approaches
choices.text: Ad hoc choice of application platforms and tooling, limited understanding of contemporary architectural approaches.

choices.value: 10#Selected vendor technology roadmap, initial understanding of new architectures and designs
choices.text: Selected vendor technology roadmap, initial understanding of new architectures and designs.

choices.value: 20#Iterative development of existing applications, limited legacy strategy, and beginnings of new development architectures
choices.text: Iterative development of existing applications, limited legacy strategy, and beginnings of new development architectures.

choices.value: 60#Focus on new application platforms and limited legacy platforms, well-defined architecture for new development projects and operating models
choices.text: Focus on new application platforms and limited legacy platforms, well-defined architecture for new development projects and operating models.

choices.value: 100#Holistic and defined overall development strategy, good designs and architectures in place and under regular review
choices.text: Holistic and defined overall development strategy, good designs and architectures in place and under regular review.

elements.name: appdev_dev_4
elements.title: What level of maturity is your source code management?

choices.value: 0#Changes are not controlled by a version control system.
choices.text: Changes are not controlled by a version control system.

choices.value: 10#Version controlled change management requires significant effort to merge for new release candidates; merges are difficult and require specialized and experienced team members to perform.
choices.text: Version controlled change management requires significant effort to merge for new release candidates; merges are difficult and require specialized and experienced team members to perform.

choices.value: 20#Code, configuration, and associated build and packaging instructions are version controlled.
choices.text: Code, configuration, and associated build and packaging instructions are version controlled.

choices.value: 40#Change merges are more straightforward, but may require high levels of coordination with external work streams that on occasion delay releases.
choices.text: Change merges are more straightforward, but may require high levels of coordination with external work streams that on occasion delay releases.

choices.value: 100#Code and configuration merges for upcoming releases are compact and incremental. Changes can be performed by all appropriate team members without being blocked by other work streams.
choices.text: Code and configuration merges for upcoming releases are compact and incremental. Changes can be performed by all appropriate team members without being blocked by other work streams.

elements.name: appdev_dev_5
elements.title: How would you describe your organization's approach to software testing?

choices.value: 0#All tests are performed manually.
choices.text: All tests are performed manually.

choices.value: 10#Some testing is automated; for example, partial unit tests coverage.
choices.text: Some testing is automated; for example, partial unit tests coverage.

choices.value: 20#Answer 2 and Automation of different kinds of testing is emerging; for example: unit, integration, regression, security, availability, and performance.
choices.text: Automation of different kinds of testing is emerging; for example: unit, integration, regression, security, availability, and performance.

choices.value: 60#Answer 3 and Quality gateways and fast feedback loops exist.
choices.text: Quality gateways and fast feedback loops exist.

choices.value: 100#Answer 4 and Defects in production are replicated via repeatable tests and added to the pipeline.
choices.text: Defects in production are replicated via repeatable tests and added to the pipeline.

elements.name: appdev_ops_1
elements.title: How would you describe the way you work with your peers and other technology specialists?

choices.value: 0#Tasks are generally worked on exclusively by individuals, and collaboration is generally low or between team members fulfilling very similar roles.
choices.text: Tasks are generally worked on exclusively by individuals, and collaboration is generally low or between team members fulfilling very similar roles.

choices.value: 10#Siloed functions are still evident, such as development, storage, networking, virtualization, security, and compliance.
choices.text: Siloed functions are still evident, such as development, storage, networking, virtualization, security, and compliance.

choices.value: 20#There are some examples of cross-functional collaboration within teams.
choices.text: There are some examples of cross-functional collaboration within teams.

choices.value: 60#Knowledge is habitually shared across technology and specialties within teams.
choices.text: Knowledge is habitually shared across technology and specialties within teams.

choices.value: 100#There are self-directed and empowered cross-functional teams.
choices.text: There are self-directed and empowered cross-functional teams.

elements.name: appdev_ops_2
elements.title: How is software prepared for distribution and deployment?

choices.value: Distributable packages created manually on users' personal devices
choices.text: Distributable packages created manually on users' personal devices

choices.value: 0#Automated build process from version controlled changes but may be reliant on special environmental configuration and libraries
choices.text: Automated build process from version controlled changes but may be reliant on special environmental configuration and libraries

choices.value: 40#Independent build process that can be run anywhere with access to declared dependencies and resources
choices.text: Independent build process that can be run anywhere with access to declared dependencies and resources

choices.value: 60#Packages built once, and once only, with a commonly understood versioning schema and with controlled access to third-party build artifacts and dependencies
choices.text: Packages built once, and once only, with a commonly understood versioning schema and with controlled access to third-party build artifacts and dependencies

choices.value: 100#Packages include consistent trackable metadata that can be used to verify configuration state of a particular runtime environment
choices.text: Packages include consistent trackable metadata that can be used to verify configuration state of a particular runtime environment

elements.name: appdev_ops_3
elements.title: Which best describes your organization's approach to software deployment?

choices.value: 0#Manual configuration and/or deployment of applications and services
choices.text: Manual configuration and/or deployment of applications and services

choices.value: 10#Some automation, but promoting between delivery stages (dev to test, test to prod, for example) done manually
choices.text: Some automation, but promoting between delivery stages (dev to test, test to prod, for example) done manually

choices.value: 20#Some examples of automated deployment processes, but created on a case-by-case basis with little reuse between applications
choices.text: Some examples of automated deployment processes, but created on a case-by-case basis with little reuse between applications

choices.value: 60#Standardized tooling used to promote applications to production
choices.text: Standardized tooling used to promote applications to production

choices.value: 100#Software releases independent of deployment into production, allowing canary or blue/green releases
choices.text: Software releases independent of deployment into production, allowing canary or blue/green releases

elements.name: appdev_ops_4
elements.title: How do you monitor and track operational performance and potential issues of applications?

choices.value: item1
choices.text: Ad hoc logging and manual monitoring of solution resources

choices.value: item2
choices.text: Standardizing logging and capturing common operational metrics

choices.value: item3
choices.text: Reacting to issues triggered by predefined alerting thresholds

choices.value: item4
choices.text: Core capabilities of the solution able to adapt and recover from failure

choices.value: item5
choices.text: Proactively testing in production including verifying potential failure states

elements.name: q_automation_1
elements.title: When building new I.T. processes, is automation a before or after thought?

choices.value: 60#Before
choices.text: Before

choices.value: 40#During
choices.text: During

choices.value: 0#After
choices.text: After

elements.name: q_automation_2
elements.title: How are technology decisions made in your organization?

choices.value: 10#Technology decisions are always solely within the department
choices.text: Technology decisions are always solely within a department.

choices.value: 40#Technology decisions are sometimes made solely within the department
choices.text: Technology decisions are sometimes made within a department and sometimes made across departments.

choices.value: 60#Technology decisions are typically made across departments
choices.text: Technology decisions are solely made across departments.

elements.name: q_automation_3
elements.title: What best describes your current approach to automating tasks?

choices.value: 0#Processes are changed in siloes.
choices.text: Processes are changed in siloes.

choices.value: 10#DevOps team changes processes.
choices.text: DevOps team changes processes.

choices.value: 40#Automation teams across the organization change processes.
choices.text: Cross-organizational teams change processes.

choices.value: 60#Multiple teams automate change processes for their components and contribute to a central repository.
choices.text: Multiple teams automate change processes for their components and contribute to a central repository.

elements.name: q_automation_4
elements.title: Which of these best describes your security practices?

choices.text: No automation used; security requirements are applied manually.
Scheduling the change window and taking things offline are implemented manually; scripts are deployed to secure systems.
Some automation is used to secure some things (e.g., OS hardening/patching).
Validation is done with automation; security processes are defined in a workflow.
All security items are applied using automation; complete with end-to-end workflow of security functions including validation.

elements.name: q_automation_6
elements.title: Do multiple teams within your organization create and share automation content in a consistent, standardized manner?

elements.name: q_automation_5
elements.title: How much automation has your organization deployed?

choices.value: 0#no automation used
choices.text: No automation is used.

choices.value: 10#teams of people writing ad-hoc scripts for automation
choices.text: Teams of people write ad hoc scripts for automation.

choices.value: 20#standardized on an automation platform; beginning to automate processes
choices.text: We’ve standardized on an automation platform, and we’re beginning to automate processes.

choices.value: 40#able to auotmate all of your day 2 tasks
choices.text: We are able to automate all of our Day 2 tasks.

choices.value: 100#all applications deployed; monitoring alerts and other IT day-to-day are automated
choices.text: All applications are deployed, and monitoring alerts and other IT day-to-day tasks are automated.

elements.name: q_automation_7
elements.title: Overall, how would you describe the level of IT automation for application development and deployment in your environment?

choices.value: 0#Level 1 Many manual steps throughout the SDLC including testing, patching, configuration, release and deployment.
choices.text: __Level 1__: Many manual steps throughout the software development life cycle (SDLC) including testing, patching, configuration, release, and deployment

choices.value: 10#Level 2 Overall processes manually coordinated, but with the emergence of scripting for simplifying repeated steps.
choices.text: __Level 2__: Overall processes manually coordinated, but with the emergence of scripting for simplifying repeated steps

choices.value: 40#Level 3 Automation coordinating the processes, with some automated testing, and the emergence of declarative configuration implementation.
choices.text: __Level 3__: Automation coordinating the processes, with some automated testing, and the emergence of declarative configuration implementation

choices.value: 60#Level 4 Significant reuse of delivery automation and automated testing now including operational concerns, but release frequency somewhat impeded by complexity of application code and configuration.
choices.text: __Level 4__: Significant reuse of delivery automation and automated testing now including operational concerns, but release frequency somewhat impeded by complexity of application code and configuration

choices.value: 100#Level 5 Software deployed to production before a managed release, with production issues being resolved through a test driven approach. Self service infrastructure with zero or little manual intervention required.
choices.text: __Level 5__: Software deployed to production before a managed release, with production issues being resolved through a test-driven approach; self-service infrastructure with zero or little manual intervention required

elements.name: q_automation_8
elements.title: How automated is your application deployment rolling out ***new*** applications?

choices.text: Manual deployment, no process or automation
Minimal deployment with ad-hoc scripting, not repeatable
Baseline continuous integration (CI) processing (unit tests, manual testing)
Advanced CI, greater than 90% automated testing, pipelines, approval gateways
Full continuous integration / continuous delivery (CI/CD) from development into production (greater than 90%)

elements.name: q_automation_9
elements.title: How automated is your application deployment rolling out ***legacy*** application updates?

choices.text: Manual deployment, no process or automation
Minimal deployment with ad-hoc scripting, not repeatable
Baseline continuous integration (CI) processing (unit tests, manual testing)
Advanced CI, greater than 90% automated testing, pipelines, approval gateways
Full continuous integration / continuous delivery (CI/CD) from development into production (greater than 90%)

elements.name: q_automation_10
elements.title: Which best describes your current automation operations process?

choices.value: 0#Core build for operating system (OS), only basic (manual) provisioning
choices.text: Core build for operating system (OS), only basic (manual) provisioning

elements.name: q_transformation_9
elements.title: Which statement best describes your incident response methodology?

choices.value: 0#No standard incident response process: No on-call rotations, incidents are worked by whomever discovers them, incidents are not tracked, no postmortem/after-incident review process
choices.text: __No standard incident response process__: No on-call rotations, incidents are worked by whomever discovers them, incidents are not tracked, no postmortem/after-incident review process

choices.value: 10#Getting started: Alerting on monitoring systems exists, but no process for managing/running the process of restoring service
choices.text: __Getting started__: Alerting on monitoring systems exists, but no process for managing/running the process of restoring service

choices.value: 20#Traditional incident response: Incident alerts are sent to a central on-call person or a network operations center (NOC); on-call engineer/NOC performs first-level attempts at service restoration according to standard playbooks, which may include Incident Managers as a position inside the organization for large-scale incidents; feature teams are not involved in on-call / incident response; postmortems/incident reviews are focused on explaining the outage/reporting to stakeholders
choices.text: __Traditional incident response__: Incident alerts are sent to a central on-call person or a network operations center (NOC) who attempts service restoration according to playbooks, Incident Managers may be a formal position for large-scale incidents; feature teams are not involved in on-call / incident response; incident reviews are focused on stakeholder explanation

choices.value: 60#Intermediate incident response: Consistent process for service restoration during an incident (using something akin to the Incident Command System), application and feature teams are on call for their functions and brought into incident response efforts as needed, developers are part of on-call rotations for their features/services
choices.text: __Intermediate incident response__: Response process uses Incident Command System or similar, developers are part of on-call rotation and incident response for their features/services

choices.value: 100#Advanced incident response: Incident response process is practiced with regularity, many trained Incident Commanders across multiple teams/functions in the organization, focus on learning from incidents and a blameless and learning focus on postmortems, a postmortem is done for every incident not only major incidents.
choices.text: __Advanced incident response__: Response process is practiced with regularity, Incident Commanders exist across multiple teams/functions, focus on learning from incidents and a blameless approach, a post-incident review is done for every incident regardless of size.
